I forgot to add:

> In general I think the bug reporting system in sourcef=
orge is the
> ideal place to be reporting bugs and/or suggesting small patc=
hes. The
> only alternative is to open up CVS to anyone who asks and who wa=
nts to
> submit a patch, which may lead to chaos. It's probably a moot poin=
t
> for SharpNeat given that there aren't more than a handful of people a
>=
 year wanting to submit a patch - but the possibility exists of the
> codeb=
ase getting out of control.

Patches against specific versions can be poste=
d anywhere Sourceforge
message forums etc so no need to open up write acces=
s to everybody.
Even if you did open write access up to many people as most=
 popular OS
projects do, you can always use "blame" mode of SVN to see who =
did
what and when, and roll back mistakes easily - so it is _very_
difficul=
t for chaos to rein :). Under most circumstances you would
only bother to r=
oll patches into the main release if they proved to be
popular/useful (it o=
nly takes a few seconds to do anyway if the patch
is done correctly - which=
 it normally is if your using subversion
clients to make the patch).  
As f=
or major branching modifications like Hyper/Parralel neat it is a
simple ma=
tter to create a branch in a SVN repository and hand out
branch write acces=
s to whoever you choose. The advantage for everyone
of this is that any bug=
 fixes, upgrades and improvements to common
code on any branch or in the ma=
in release can easily be merged across
or patches created (by anyone not ju=
st code maintainers) so all
flavors of SharpNeat can benefit from the hard =
work...
